figure.alt: Your roadmap should be a sequence of problems you want to solve, not features. Your success metrics should be agreed upon while you are defining the problem, not the solution.

node.excerpt: Always helpful to be reminded of this point. Instead of continuously building features for those who shout loudest, we need to focus on the problems our users face and then identify how we'll solve
node.content:
Always helpful to be reminded of this point. Instead of continuously building features for those who shout loudest, we need to focus on the problems our users face and then identify how we'll solve them.

Preach! pic.twitter.com/e6z8odsblH

— Richard Banfield (@RMBanfield) November 9, 2019

node.title: Behind Every Great Product by Marty Cagan at Mind the Product London 2016

figure.alt: Behind Every Great Product by Marty Cagan at Mind the Product London 2016

node.excerpt: In the opening keynote at this year’s London MTPCon, Silicon Valley Product Group’s Marty Cagan shared his latest thoughts on what makes a great product manager by looking at the history of some
node.content: In the opening keynote at this year’s London MTPCon, Silicon Valley Product Group’s Marty Cagan shared his latest thoughts on what makes a great product manager by looking at the history of some great products.
